{code}

DNS properties

{code}
euca-describe-properties  | grep -E '(dns|domain)'
PROPERTY	bootstrap.webservices.use_dns_delegation	true
PROPERTY	bootstrap.webservices.use_instance_dns	true
PROPERTY	cloud.vmstate.instance_subdomain	.eucalyptus
PROPERTY	dns.dns_listener_address_match	0.0.0.0
PROPERTY	dns.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.instancedata.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.ns.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.recursive.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.services.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.services.hostmapping	{}
PROPERTY	dns.split_horizon.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.spoof_regions.enabled	false
PROPERTY	dns.spoof_regions.region_name	{}
PROPERTY	dns.spoof_regions.spoof_aws_default_regions	false
PROPERTY	dns.spoof_regions.spoof_aws_regions	false
PROPERTY	dns.tcp.timeout_seconds	30
PROPERTY	loadbalancing.loadbalancer_dns_subdomain	lb
PROPERTY	objectstorage.s3provider.s3usebackenddns	false
PROPERTY	system.dns.dnsdomain	localhost
PROPERTY	system.dns.nameserver	nshost.localhost
PROPERTY	system.dns.nameserveraddress	10.104.10.38
PROPERTY	system.dns.registrationid	20e34231-e5f7-4363-9e7c-9ca95b25bf73
{code}

DNS listener

{code}
# netstat -tulpn | grep 53
tcp        0      0 10.104.10.38:53             0.0.0.0:*                   LISTEN      22740/eucalyptus-cl 
udp        0      0 10.104.10.38:53             0.0.0.0:*                               22740/eucalyptus-cl
{code}

Now I try to perform a name resolution for compute service against the DNS like this

{code}
# dig compute.localhost @10.104.10.38 +notcp

; <<>> DiG 9.8.2rc1-RedHat-9.8.2-0.23.rc1.el6_5.1 <<>> compute.localhost @10.104.10.38 +notcp
;; global options: +cmd
;; connection timed out; no servers could be reached
{code}

As can be seen, it does not work. If I now try with TCP Handler , it works

{code}
# dig compute.localhost @10.104.10.38 +tcp

; <<>> DiG 9.8.2rc1-RedHat-9.8.2-0.23.rc1.el6_5.1 <<>> compute.localhost @10.104.10.38 +tcp
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 13903
;; flags: qr aa rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 2, AUTHORITY: 0, ADDITIONAL: 0

;; QUESTION SECTION:
;compute.localhost.		IN	A

;; ANSWER SECTION:
compute.localhost.	60	IN	A	10.104.10.48
compute.localhost.	60	IN	A	10.104.10.38

;; Query time: 27 msec
;; SERVER: 10.104.10.38#53(10.104.10.38)
;; WHEN: Fri Jun 27 01:22:24 2014
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 67
{code}

UDP handler not working causes issue with name resolution with the default stub resolver in Linux hence making the system unusable in this topology. 

Feel free to close this as duplicate if there is already an issue for this problem. In case you have any questions please let me know.

Cheers!
Deependra

comments.body:
[~kedwards] use case is that after enabling DNS and re-downloading creds (then source them) none of the euca-* commands work. They all get hung up for a while and show 'connection error' on further debugging I found that resolving the DNS name for the service endpoints does not work. The /etc/resolv.conf on the Linux machine where this was seen pointed to the CLC IP as the primary DNS server so normally we would expect resolutions to work when euca-* commands are invoked. 

Hence user cannot use client tools to connect to a 4.0.0 cloud after the DNS is enabled. Please let me know if you have any further questions.
[~kedwards] what is the update on this issue ?

[~dshekhawat], "cloud controller configured to use itself for name resolution" means that the system DNS resolution settings on the CLC host point to the CLCs DNS service (causing the CLC to incorrectly attempt to use itself for recursive DNS lookups)

[~sjones] still not clear, can you please confirm if you meant {{/etc/resolv.conf}} when you said "system DNS resolution settings on the CLC host" ? Or does it mean the cloud property {{system.dns.nameserveraddress}}

[~dshekhawat] I think he meant /etc/resolv.conf. When that file points to CLC host, the DNS service's recursive DNS look up uses itself. It is like calling a C function "void do_this() {  do_this(); }".
[~spark] , [~sjones], in that case /etc/resolv.conf does not point to CLC at all. It points to the upstream DNS server.

Support/PRC testing complete. Synopsis below.

TL;DR It works, and it works really quite well!

So I took this ticket and began by setting up a nominal cloud (1 frontend, 1 NC), since the focus here was the DNS performance. I started out with 4.0.0, since that's what the customer was on when they reported the issue (and that's what the EUCA indicates as the version reported).

I set up a new subdomain (jimc2.cs.prc.eucalyptus-systems.com) and configured the DNS properties as appropriate.

I spent some time with dig and dnsperf inside of a CentOS 6.5 instance, first validating correct DNS functionality using dig, then burning the heck out of the CLC's DNS with dnsperf (1000 iterations), then confirming that dig would fail to do the lookup with the +notcp flag, but still succeed with the +tcp flag.

I then proceeded with shutting down the components and upgrading to 4.0.2, and starting with a fresh CentOS 6.5 instance, then repeated the dig and dnsperf tests above.

It's absolutely SOLID now. Pre-upgrade, dnsperf performance was okay but not amazing, possibly due to having choked out the DNS service early on. Post-upgrade I was able to easily do 100,000 iterations (2 orders of magnitude above what I tested pre-upgrade) in just over 6 seconds! And no query failures!

Sharing for your enjoyment:

where 10.104.10.24 is the IP of the CLC.

I confirmed the sanity of the CLC DNS service with a few dig runs, testing both +tcp and +notcp. Solid. I even went back and beat on it some more with dnsperf, and the DNS services were completely unfazed. Still solid.

[~jcarroll], I think the reported issue was that when the DNS server used for recursive name resolution is either incorrectly configured or temporarily unavailable the CLC DNS service becomes unresponsive (all threads blocked waiting for responses from external DNS server)

Right, so the issue my customer was seeing was that they could cause a DNS DoS by overloading it temporarily. It would eventually clear on its own (within less than 5 mins, but I never tried to nail down precisely) but that didn't address the customer's primary concern, which was a loss of DNS services. Using dnsperf was a way to quickly get it into a failed state, with at most 1000 iterations. The 4.0.2 fix prevents this failure from happening, at least from my testing with dnsperf using 100,000 iterations.

After chatting with Harold, it seems there might have been confusion due to having pasted output from dnsperf, but not from dig.

Here's a timeline of test activities, to help correlate vs the logs. Times are local to the PRC machine (PST):

Thu Nov 20 10:30:10 PST 2014 - started dnsperf, kicked off this while loop:

where 7458 was the only eucalyptus-cloud PID

repeated dig query, waited for failure, waited a couple secs, retried until success

Thu Nov 20 10:33:50 PST 2014 - after this timestamp, terminated 'while' loop

Escalation information provided by Tier 2:
{quote}
*Assessment* 
When the CLC DNS service is overloaded (from an instance using dnsperf), it stops responding for a period of time. During that period, 'dig' fails to return any queries, regardless of whether +tcp or +notcp is used. Of particular interest to the customer is when the query is a recursive one, designed to retried a CNAME record which resolves to the A record for the instance which ran the queries (both dnsperf as well as dig).

*Signs* 
CNC DNS service becomes unresponsive, at least when it's hammered with queries (from an instance) intended to be recursive in nature. Of possible interest is that the original query is for a CNAME record which in turn references the A record for the instance where the multiple queries are being executed.

*Actions* 
1. starve CLC DNS service using dnsperf 
2. before CLC DNS has a chance to recover, query for CNAME record using dig, wait for failure 
3. wait a few mins 
4. try dig command again [with more waiting and retries, as needed] until CLC DNS resumes returning records as per usual

Note: The CLC DNS service seems to recover within 2-3 mins, although I haven't been able to precisely nail down the duration.

*Workaround* 
a) restart CLC, or, 
b) wait until CLC DNS service resumes normal operations
{quote}

In the reproduction procedure, it appears dnsperf and dig are not targeting specially the CLC as the dns server. The result with dns.jomax.net in the authority section is when you query against 8.8.8.8. I'd remove any other DNS servers from resolv.conf before running the test.

[~hspencer] it appears that dnsperf is issuing lots of queries until before the outstanding queries return. This eats up all the allocated threads on the CLC's dns server. You can limit this by -q option in dnsperf.
 dnsperf -d ./queryfile -s 10.104.10.55 -n 2000 -q 3

[~mmunn1] I think the immediate fix for 4.1 is to increase the thread pool for the DNS handler (UDPHandler line 135). Currently it's 30 (as default) and that should be increased to a couple hundreds. Then we can use the same dnsperf to verify the fix.
[~spark] Thanks, I will make those changes and test it out.
[~spark] Do we want to make this customer configurable as a DNS property?
[~mmunn1] I think that's reasonable.

Code Review Request : EUCA-9602 UDP handler is not working

branch : dev/mmunn1/EUCA-9602

diff :  git show --color 3af5a4c8dcc693d1437733bc91fa6be625c92cef


Summary: UDP handler hangs with too many dns requsts and availble threads are used up.

Solution: Make the dns worker threads configurable so that customer can increse the number of threads for the expected load.

Unit test : described in comments
The property description should reflect that this setting is for UDP only, looks good to me otherwise.
[~sjones] Thanks Steve I will change the Description to indicate UDP only.
[~sjones] I am thinking we may want to rename the property dns.udp.num_worker_threads instead of  dns.num_worker_threads, your thoughts on this?
[~mmunn1], that would be more consistent, as tcp specific properties begin with "dns.tcp.".

[~mmunn1] Can we increase the default # handlers? I think the default 32 is too low and people will come across the problem again. I guess we need a benchmark (with the CNAME setup) to pick the right number.
[~spark] 200 works correctly with the cname setup, I left the default as is (32) so the we do not change the behavior of existing customer setups.

[~mmunn1] I don't think increasing the value would impact the behavior of the existing setup (unless people complain about the response time being too fast :-). To me then 128 would be a reasonable number to start with. What do you think?
[~spark] That sounds good to me I will set the default to 128.
[~spark] Done,  I changed the default to 128
[~mmunn1] woot!

[~hspencer] [~dshekhawat] [~smaynard] Here's the summary and workaround --

* The fix we put in 4.0.2 and 4.1.0 works
* However, the default # of threads is not enough to handle the client's benchmark. 
* The fix also has an issue (EUCA-10626, EUCA-10624), which may cause this issue happening again under different benchmark/system-load.
* Workaround: 
 -- set # of threads to 512: euca-modify-property -p dns.udp.num_worker_threads=512
 -- due to EUCA-10624, changing the value doesn't take effect until cloud restarts.  To make the immediate effect, they need to use this hacky command line: 
euca-modify-property -p 'euca=com.eucalyptus.system.Threads.workers.remove("Dns:EphemeralConfiguration:arn:euca:eucalyptus::dns:com.eucalyptus.cloud.ws.UDPHandler/\[workers\]")'
* After the workaround, the benchmark using dnsperf will work fine. I noticed a small % (about 1%) of lost queries in some cases, but I see 100% completion most of time.
---------------------------------------------------------
